column1: Oxygen is a gas that the cells in your body need to work properly.
Babies with heart or lung problems may need to breathe increased amounts of oxygen to get normal levels of oxygen in their blood.
An oxygen hood is used for babies who can breathe on their own but still need extra oxygen.
Finally, a breathing machine or ventilator may be needed to deliver increased oxygen and breathe for the baby.
Too much oxygen can also cause injury.
Under certain conditions, too much oxygen in the blood may also lead to problems in the brain and eye.
Babies with certain heart conditions may also need lower levels of oxygen in the blood.
If you have questions about the risks and benefits of oxygen for your baby, discuss these with your baby's doctor.
Infants receiving oxygen by hood may get cold if the temperature of the oxygen is not warm enough.
At higher flow rates, this can irritate the inner nose, causing cracked skin, bleeding, or mucus plugs in the nose.
